etymologies: late 17th century (in the former sense ‘place in which an insect deposits its eggs’): from Latin, literally ‘nest’

definitions: a place in which bacteria have multiplied or may multiply; a focus of infection

examples.text: abscesses and scarring were present which would be consistent with an initial nidus of infection in the lung

shortDefinitions: place in which bacteria have multiplied or may multiply

definitions: a place or situation in which something develops or is fostered

examples.text: many models of society see the main nidus of struggle residing in the sphere of production

shortDefinitions: place in which something develops or is fostered
